author: reactdev123
content: Great overview! I'd add that understanding Web Components is becoming increasingly important too. They provide a framework-agnostic way to build reusable components.

replies.author: webcomponent_fan
replies.content: Absolutely agree! Lit and Stencil are making Web Components much more approachable. The interoperability is a huge advantage.

replies.author: techguru42
replies.content: Good point! I should have included Web Components. They're especially valuable in large organizations with multiple frontend teams using different frameworks.

author: performanceguru
content: The Core Web Vitals point is crucial. I've seen sites lose 30% of their traffic just from poor CLS scores. Tools like Partytown for third-party scripts are game-changers.

replies.author: seoexpert
replies.content: This! Google is getting stricter about Core Web Vitals. I recommend running Lighthouse CI in your deployment pipeline.

author: jspatterns
content: This repository is incredible! The compound component pattern explanation alone saved me hours of research. Thanks for sharing!

author: reactnewbie
content: Perfect timing! I was just struggling with prop drilling. The context pattern examples are exactly what I needed.

replies.author: reactdev2024
replies.content: Glad it helped! The render props section is also worth checking out - it's a powerful pattern that's often overlooked.

author: statemanagement
content: I made the same switch 6 months ago and haven't looked back. The DevTools experience is also much better - you can see state changes in real-time without the Redux DevTools complexity.

replies.author: zustandfan
replies.content: Yes! The DevTools integration is so clean. And the middleware system is powerful but optional - you only add complexity when you need it.

replies.author: devtools_lover
replies.content: The time-travel debugging in Zustand DevTools is fantastic. Much easier to use than Redux DevTools.

author: reduxfan
content: But what about time-travel debugging? Redux DevTools are still unmatched for complex state debugging scenarios.

replies.author: zustandfan
replies.content: Zustand actually supports time-travel debugging too! Check out the redux DevTools middleware. It's optional but available when you need it.

author: mindfultech
content: This is why I've started using apps like Forest and Cold Turkey. We need technological solutions to technological problems. Great breakdown of the psychology!

replies.author: digitalpsych
replies.content: Forest is great! I also recommend turning off all non-essential notifications. The average person checks their phone 96 times a day - mostly due to notification triggers.

author: uxdesigner
content: As a designer, I feel conflicted about this. We're taught to optimize for engagement, but where's the line between good UX and manipulation? The industry needs better ethical guidelines.

replies.author: ethicaltech
replies.content: Check out the Center for Humane Technology - they're working on exactly these kinds of ethical design frameworks. We need more designers thinking like you!

author: gopher_dev
content: Great writeup! I had a similar experience coming from Go. The ownership model was the biggest hurdle, but once it clicks, you start to see memory bugs in other languages everywhere.

replies.author: rustnovice
replies.content: Exactly! I can't unsee potential null pointer dereferences in JavaScript now. Rust really changes how you think about memory safety.

author: rust_beginner
content: Currently in month 2 of learning Rust and definitely in the struggle phase! This gives me hope. Any specific resources you'd recommend for the ownership concepts?

replies.author: rustnovice
replies.content: The 'Rust Ownership Explained' series on YouTube by Jon Gjengset is fantastic. Also, try implementing a simple linked list - it forces you to understand borrowing deeply.

replies.author: linkedlist_fan
replies.content: The linked list suggestion is brutal but effective! I spent 3 days on it but learned more about Rust than in the previous month.
